head.supplied: 31/7/89 ¶ ¶ By this mail, dear Mr Dyer, I send you specimens of all the kinds of ferns, gathered by Sir Will MacGregor in his ascent of the Owen Stanley's Ranges, ¶ an exploit, which I had urged for...

div.p: RBG Kew, Kew correspondence, Australia, Mueller, 1882-90, ff. 283-4.

31/7/89
Date stamped: Royal Gardens Kew — 9 Sep. 89. Annotated in pencil by D. Oliver D. O. and in red ink by Thiselton-Dyer: And 22.9.89 and List 10.10.89 (neither letter nor list has been found).

By this mail, dear Mr Dyer, I send you specimens of all the kinds of ferns, gathered by Sir Will MacGregor in his ascent of the Owen Stanley's Ranges,
Papua New Guinea. See Argus, 15 July 1889, p. 5. an exploit, which I had urged for many years, and the importance of which I impressed in a personal interview here on his Honor. As Mr Carruthers works on Mr Forbes's Papuan ferns, I have sent to the British Museum a second set; — and you can of course make special arrangements with Mr Carruthers for dealing at Kew scientifically with these ferns, those from the subalpine heights being particularly interesting
See M to W. Carruthers, 31 July 1889 (in this edition as 89-07-31a). To Dr Masters I will send for the Gardeners-Chronicle a few hurried notes on the genera, represented in the cold zone of New Guinea, the commigration being very remarkable and significant.
B90.06.01.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;
font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;

div.p:
A set of the Phanerogams from Sir Will. MacGregor's last expedition will also be sent to Kew; so soon as elaborated.
B90.06.04. The specimens are however in a poor state, and represent not very many sp. as they had to be carried down the steep declivities through the wet jungles in the empty provision-bags. From this melange , I prepared the specimens. I will see, that this alpine exploration of New Guinea is followed up, so far as I can speed it, but to prepare good bot. specimens in early explorations is very diffcult indeed.
Lycopodiaceae I have only sent to you.
